description:
Brevibacterium picturae is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Brevibacterium. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. The cells of B. picturae are typically short, rod-shaped, and occur singly or in pairs.

This species was first isolated from the surface of a painted artwork, hence the specific epithet "picturae" which means "of a painting" in Latin. B. picturae is known to be capable of colonizing and growing on the surface of paintings, particularly those that have been exposed to environmental conditions such as moisture and microbial contamination.

Phylogenetically, B. picturae is closely related to other Brevibacterium species and shares similarities in terms of its biochemical characteristics and DNA sequence. However, it can be distinguished from other members of the genus by its unique physiological and genetic properties.

The ability of B. picturae to thrive on the surface of paintings highlights its potential role in the biodeterioration of cultural heritage materials. Understanding the biology and ecology of this species can contribute to the development of strategies for the preservation and conservation of artworks.
